results.title: Shonky golf with Mick Molloy
results.creator_credit: Mick Molloy, Penelope Everett, Emma Moss, Stephen Luby and Radiant Industries
results.brief_description: Mick Molloy, together with his coach and caddy, Alan Length, have compiled this instructional video about how to improve oneself at shonky golf. Together they cover areas such as the fundamentals (not just grip, but how to find a good parking spot in the carpark); getting the most out of the pro shop; navigating trouble spots; the mechanics of the golf cart; your relationship with the caddy, future directions in golfing attire, and most importantly, etiquette on the golf course. Put their advice into practice and you too can dubiously navigate your way around the green.

results.title: Shoah: first era
results.creator_credit: Claude Lanzmann and Les Films Aleph
results.brief_description: Director Claude Lanzmann’s ‘Shoah’ (the Hebrew word for destruction or annihilation), attempts to create in the present the reality of the Holocaust through the memories of its survivors, both victims and perpetrators. This remarkable documentary achieves this without a single use of archival or found footage, rather letting the horror of the Holocaust resonate through the myriad of stories and the faces of the survivors. Lanzmann and his documentary crew take their subjects through the now abandoned fields and buildings of their past torment, as they recount and talk the viewer through the unknowable and unthinkable. Images such as disused train tracks, overgrown with grass and leading nowhere take on a chilling and profound resonance as we are left to contemplate what happened there. Winner of the 1985 New York Film Critics Circle Award and the 1985 National Society of Film Critics Awards-USA.

results.title: Short and suite
results.creator_credit: Evelyn Lambart, Norman McLaren and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A colour cocktail by Norman McLaren and Evelyn Lambart, translating into moving patterns of colour and light the moods of music written for a jazz ensemble by Eldon Rathburn. Inscribed and coloured directly on film. (Awards: Venice; Bergamo.)

results.title: Shipmates
results.brief_description: Emily brings her friends home to the Cape Otway Lighthouse for her twelfth birthday. Her fisherman friend Jack gives her a model of the “Loch Ard” one of the clipper ships which foundered on the coast. Jack is keen to catch the tagged fish which will win him a new boat. But the “Loch Ard” has plans of its own. Rated: G

results.title: Shoppingtown
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Peter Leovic and David Caesar
results.brief_description: Short Australian film by David Caesar which creates a portrait of Parramatta Shoppingtown in August 1986. Initial blank screen isolates people’s words as they voice their aspirations and understanding of happiness. Silence follows as a series of film portraits reveal the inhabitants of Shoppingtown, a shopping centre in suburban Sydney. A rapid montage of images and sounds, most prominently the sounds of the checkout scanner, denote the commercial aspect of a space which has been established in the film as communal and civic. The portraits of shoppers and mall dwellers return, ending in a portrait of the filmmakers themselves.

results.title: Shine
results.creator_credit: Scott Hicks, Jane Scott and Momentum Films
results.brief_description: The award winning film “Shine” tells the remarkable story of pianist David Helfgott. As a child prodigy he was expected to have a brilliant career, but a nervous breakdown on the brink of international success meant that he was institutionalised and without access to the instrument which he loved so much. His voyage out of that darkness into a life which became filled with love, is truly inspirational. Noah Taylor and Geoffrey Rush give exceptional performances as Helfgott, while Armin Mueller-Stahl who plays David’s father is outstanding. “Shine” was a triumph internationally for both the Australian film industry and the relaunching of Helfgott’s career. It is also a testament to the courage of human beings facing adversity and overcome it. Geoffrey Rush received an Academy Award for his outstanding performance.

results.title: Alcheringa
results.brief_description: Bill Onus hosts this series of films on different aspects of the traditional lifestyle of Australian Aborigines.
results.description: Bill Onus hosts this series of films on different aspects of the traditional lifestyle of Australian Aborigines.

results.title: Woman gathers food
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Alcheringa”.
To the women falls the task of collecting supplementary foods - such as witchetty grubs and yams. Use is made of a sharply pointed stick to dig under bark for grubs and to kill a lizard which wanders across their path; also to dig for yams. The daughter accompanies her mother on her daily walk and learns the art of food gathering.

results.title: Walkabout
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
An Aboriginal man and his wife undertake a pilgrimage to the sacred place of the Rainbow Serpent, the controller of rain, water and life on earth. They are shown walking to the coast through an uninhabited land, clambering down cliffs to the ocean. The man carries spears and always walks ahead. Their way of life in tribal times is clearly shown in this brief sequence, as the man carries two spears and walks ahead of his wife.

results.title: Shiloh
results.creator_credit: Dale Rosenbloom, Zane W. Levitt, Zeta Entertainment and Utopia Pictures
results.brief_description: Blake Heron stars as Marty Preston, an average kid who lives in an average American small town with his Mum and his mailman Dad (Michael Moriarty). One day Marty finds an injured beagle that’s run away from its abusive owner. Kindly neighbour Doc Wallace (Rod Steiger) tends to the dog’s wounds, but Marty’s father explains that they must return the dog to its rightful owner. Marty knows that Shiloh belongs to someone else, but he is determined to save the dog from more neglect. Against the wishes of his father, Marty risks everything to make the dog his own. This is a story of determination and strength, based on the children’s book of the same name by Phyllis Reynolds Naylor.
